title: Manual Scaffold Assignment
introduction:
After cutting and joining contigs, the next step is organizing them into scaffolds (chromosome-level assemblies). Scaffold assignment lets you group related contigs and assign them to specific chromosomes.

In this lesson, you'll work with the crocodile genome to learn scaffold management: creating scaffolds, assigning contigs, reordering sequences, and using visual color bands to track your organization. This is essential for producing a chromosome-level assembly.

steps.title: Enter Scaffold Mode
steps.instruction:
To work with scaffolds, switch to Scaffold mode using the mode selector in the toolbar.

In Scaffold mode, you can:
• Create new scaffolds (chromosomes)
• Assign contigs to scaffolds
• Rename and color-code scaffolds
• Reorder contigs within scaffolds

Scaffold mode also displays colored bands on the contact map, helping you visualize which contigs belong to which chromosome.
steps.hint: Look for the 'Scaffold' option in the mode selector. It's typically next to 'View' and 'Edit' modes.

steps.title: Create a New Scaffold
steps.instruction:
Let's create your first scaffold. In the scaffold panel (usually on the right side), click the 'New Scaffold' or '+' button.

Give your scaffold a meaningful name like 'Chromosome 1' or 'Chr1'. You can also assign it a color to make it visually distinct on the map.

Scaffolds serve as containers for grouping related contigs into chromosome-level assemblies.
steps.hint: The scaffold creation button is usually in the scaffold management panel. Look for a '+' or 'Add' button.

steps.title: Assign Contigs to Scaffold
steps.instruction:
Now assign contigs to your new scaffold. There are several ways to do this:

1. Select contigs in the map (click or Shift+click for multiple)
2. Click 'Assign to Scaffold' and choose your scaffold
3. The contigs will be grouped and colored accordingly

Try assigning a few contigs that clearly belong to the same chromosome (look for contigs within the same diagonal block).
steps.hint: Start with contigs in one of the bright diagonal blocks. These likely form a complete chromosome.

steps.title: Use Drag Mode for Reordering
steps.instruction:
You can reorder contigs within a scaffold using drag-and-drop. This is especially useful for fine-tuning the linear order to match the Hi-C signal.

To reorder:
1. Make sure you're in a mode that allows dragging (Edit or Scaffold)
2. Click and hold on a contig in the sidebar
3. Drag it to a new position
4. Release to drop it

The contact map updates immediately to show the new ordering.
steps.hint: Drag-and-drop works in the sidebar contig list. Try moving a contig up or down to see how the map changes.

steps.title: Reorder Contigs in the Assembly
steps.instruction:
Practice reordering contigs to optimize the contact map. The goal is to maximize the bright signal along the diagonal.

When contigs are in the correct order:
• Strong signal stays on the diagonal
• Off-diagonal artifacts decrease
• Chromosome blocks look clean and square

Try moving a few contigs around and observe how the contact pattern changes. Use undo if you make things worse!
steps.hint: Watch the contact map as you reorder. The signal should become stronger on the diagonal when contigs are in the right order.

steps.title: Review Your Scaffold Assignments
steps.instruction:
Take a moment to review your scaffold assignments:

• Check the scaffold panel to see which contigs are assigned
• Look at the colored bands on the contact map
• Verify that each scaffold contains contigs from a single chromosome block

You can create multiple scaffolds and assign different chromosome blocks to each one. This organizational structure is what gets exported when you save the curated assembly.
steps.hint: Well-organized scaffolds make it easy to export chromosome-level assemblies in formats like AGP, BED, or FASTA.

steps.title: Scaffold Management Summary
steps.instruction:
Congratulations! You've learned scaffold assignment:

• Creating new scaffolds (chromosomes)
• Assigning contigs to scaffolds
• Using drag-and-drop to reorder contigs
• Visual feedback with colored bands
• Reviewing and organizing your work

Scaffolds are the bridge between raw contigs and chromosome-level assemblies. In the next lesson, you'll put all your skills together in a full curation exercise.

Tip: Export your scaffolds to AGP format to use in other genomics tools!
steps.hint: Scaffold mode is one of the most powerful features in OpenPretext. Practice organizing different genomes to build your expertise.
